"Paris in the Fall. The last months of the year and the end of the millennium. The city holds many memories for me; of cafés, or music, of love and of death." - George StobbartHere is the beginning of Revolution Software's iconic adventure game series, starting its journey in 1996: Broken Sword: The Shadow of the Templars. Has it really been 20 years? Wow, now I feel really old. Yet, this is not the original game. This is the director's cut version of the '96 original developed as an adaptation to handhold series, later ported into iOS and Android, eventually getting ported to PC again. Even though, it might be considered a lesser version of the original for many reasons that I will later share in the review, it is a marvelous and memorable adventure game title and a must for everyone who enjoys the genre.As a major change to the original version, the game begins with Nicole Collard, satirical, ambitious and crafty photo-journalist of La Liberté, making a research about a costume killer whose been targeting various VIPs around the world, instead of our actual protagonist, George Stobbart, an American tourist and lawyer visiting Paris for the sole reason of having a vacation. Whatever the pace of the start would be, they are soon to cross roads as the café George's been visiting at the time blows up, killing Nico's informant and ruining George's vacation. From that point onwards, their interests get intertwined and together, they start a long journey over the globe tracking the killer, following obscure leads from medieval ages signifying a grand conspiracy about Templar Knights and Hashashins.See, Broken Sword series was dabbling with Templars and Assassins before it was cool! Well, if we are to go back to the story, one heart-breaking change for me was the introduction. The original game starts with George's iconic narrative and café blowing, Nico later showing up as part of the narrative pace. Here in Director's Cut version, Nico is introduced as a playable character with a side story and the game starts with her investigation. I have to say that Nico's side story, even though enjoyable, feels like a sore thumb in the original narrative. You see, that part was never intended to be there to begin with. It slows the pace of the original story by introducing completely unrelated information to the main story. Plus, those parts are presented in a drastically different graphics quality compared to the original game. It just doesn't fit.The narrative of the game, characters and anecdotal encounters are all marvelously funny and witty with a history buff on the foreground. The game is one of the early examples of humor dominated settings in adventure games. All characters are lovable eccentrics with situational comedy elements. Sadly, I have to note that Director's Cut version actually "cuts" dialogue and animation content from the original game, somewhat downgrading the flow and the atmosphere of the whole story. It is not incredibly noticeable if you haven't played the original first, but it is there.As for the display quality, I have already stated that there is a clash between the original parts and the newly added story part. Graphics look like hand-drawn, animated cartoons with lovely exaggerations. One other down side of the Director's Cut is that there are truckload of missing character animations. They seem weirdly idle this way. During dialogues, close-ups of characters are added to the top of the screen. The animation style for those are a bit questionable too, if you ask me. Music is just as lovely as always though. The original soundtrack is heavily recommended for your enjoyment.For the gameplay, it is your quite basic point and click adventure. You collect items, talk to people about on-goings, solve puzzles etc. Here again, I have to note some more distasteful changes that Director's Cut version introduces. Firstly, your pointer shines with a blue circle whenever it is near a point of interest, completely killing investigative expectation of the game. It's like following a series of arrows or a giant plate that says "this way" from the start 'till the end. It is demeaningly simplified. Animations of puzzles - and their total count actually - are changed also. They are downright simple with no downsides to lookout for. One other change that has broken my heart was the newly introduced inability to die. Whatever you do or say, George will prevail now. In the original version, there would be certain choices that could get you killed. Now, George refuses to do said actions to begin with. So long for cause-consequence there.By the end, can I actually recommend this game? Sure, without skipping a heartbeat. I can only strongly advise for you to play the original version - which can be reached via GOG, rather than this watered down version called as Director's Cut. It is a marvelous little story with memorable characters, an adventurous build and anecdotal history with conspiracy theories. Also a part of computer adventure genre history at this point. It is still as fresh and lovely as the first time around. What else do you need from an adventure game anyhow?UPDATE: Original version of the game is added to the Steam now, as a downloadable DLC for this Director's Cut version. Enjoy!Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

												Broken Sword: Director’s Cut does a lot of the little things wrong. Back in 1996, the player was thrown out into a graphic noir world very much like our own, one brimming over with unique personalities who don’t think of themselves as cogs in a giant machine, but people getting suitably annoyed at the pushy American who won’t stop showing people the soiled tissue he found in the sewers and asking them if it means anything to them. Now updated, a lot of the dialogue options are cut in an attempt to streamline the adventure, making the Templar mysteries a significantly greater focus point, but in doing so, it robs the title of so much of its former wealth. Interactive hotspots are not only slashed in half, but are made instantly visible, taking away the nagging frustration of room-sweeping with your mouse to find them yourself, but also highlighting just how much the new version wants to hold your hand. Including an in-game hint system is understandable: a stuck player only needs visit numerous online walkthroughs should they decide coping with their frustration early is better than the cerebral rewards of working through a puzzle, but gone also are the numerous instances where George could make a fatal mistake. Leave an exclusive French hotel with an important and newly-discovered clue, and fail to remember the pair of Italian gangsters hanging around the entrance, and the last thing you’ll remember before being gifted a pair of concrete shoes and invited for a swim is an aggressive frisking and an insincere goodbye. Now, try and leave through the same door, and George will warn you that it’s not a good idea. Then tells you exactly why!Full review -- http://www.honestgamers.com/9033/pc/broken-sword-directors-cut/review.html

												I love Broken Sword. It's one of my favorite adventure games of all time, I grew up with it. Hearing about an update to one of my favorite games made me weary but I remained optimistic. Naturally, I tried to like it. But I just can't.This revision completely butchered the original on so many levels; it's a disgrace. I am majorly disappointed with how this was handled. The new arc doesn't bring anything new or interesting to the table (especially if you never played the original before, newcomers get nothing out of this new story) and seems unnecessarily tacked on. It explores a side story that is negligible in the greater context and waters down the impact of the original story's writing and pacing immensely. The new environments, icons and character models look really out of place when displayed right next to their by now 17 year old assets which in my opinion negatively impacts the immersion and cohesiveness: the clashing art styles and different asset qualities make the game feel terribly stitched together. The shoddy new UI (which is optimized for touchscreen devices; use of a cursor feels awkward which is a disaster considering the original is a Point & Click classic), automatically displayed points of interaction as well as the help system make the game unbearable when you are familiar with the original. Revolution went to the extremes with the handholding which is terribly annoying: everything is pointed out to you and instantly made visible. You never feel taken seriously as a player and it's almost as if the game doesn't want or need your skills to be solved. It rather points at everything with a flashy sign as if you were near-blind.Sadly, Revolution took the phrase Directors 'Cut' a bit too literally. Removed were details like waving flags, idle animations and ambient sounds but also integral parts of the game like dialogue and entire scenes. The cut narrative aspects break the game's story and writing, which was already impaired by the new sidestory. The missing details destroy the charm the original used to have, the charm that made players fall in love this game. This content was removed for absolutely no logical reason and is a decision of the developer I can't understand or get behind. Who thought this was a good idea? Cutting parts of your story doesn't do the game's pacing any favors whatsoever.The most jarring of all the omissions however is that you can't die. This is absolute nonsense. The original version of Broken Sword had a ton of situations where wrong decisions could get you killed (Video Contains Spoilers). Presumably, this was done in order to save the player from losing too much or all of their progress. Removing this aspect however, eliminates incredibly much suspense and is a case of game design decisions meant to appeal to a contemporary audience causing the loss of a lot of suspense, gameplay, atmosphere and ultimately enjoyment for the player.If you are curious about the extent of the changes, you can find some of them here: http://www.movie-censorship.com/report.php?ID=254238Regardless whether you experienced the original or not, use ScummVM to play the original release if you can obtain it (Or purchase it via GOG where you will receive both versions with one purchase) and let this abomination rot in the store. You will get a more polished, detailed and cohesive gameplay experience out of it.Who knows what Charles Cecil and Revolution were thinking. But it certainly wasn't anything good.--EDIT: Fixed a few typos and revised wording.--Please note that I previously purchased this version of the game outside of Steam (iOS) and completed it, the playtime recorded by Steam is not indicative of my total experience with the Director's Cut version.

												Before we get into this let me just say that I love Broken Sword. The original Broken Sword. I have probably completed it more times than I have other games in my library. I especially go back to it now and again to experience its world, its characters and its humour.So you can imagine my excitement when finding this "Directors Cut" edition on Steam.Unfortunately I simply could never recommend this version to anyone who wishes to experience Broken Sword and see what all the fuss was about back in the day.If you really want to play Broken Sword nowadays, there is a "Broken Sword Trilogy" DVD-based package that you can buy on Amazon or EBay (ie. a non-Steam release) and it includes a perfect working version of the actual original Broken Sword and it will work with modern hardware and OS. So go for that.As for the problems with this version? There are so many to talk about...- Missing dialogue which affects the humour and even misses vital plot points.- MIssing animations (NPC characters no longer have a talking animation, the flags no longer flutter in the breeze at the Hotel Ubu).- Missing interactions with certain objects throughout the game (such as just about everything in the museum, you can't read the patients medical records in the hospital, you can't read the historical information on the boards at Montfaucon).- Missing cut scenes such as when you first enter the castle in Ireland.- Missing interactions with entire characters in some locations (such as the guy in the middle bed in the hospital).- Sound glitches whereby I heard Lady Piermonts piano playing in other random locations (amongst other problems).- A clear difference in recording quality between the new dialogue and the old dialogue (especially noticeable with a headset).- The additional scenario as Nico offers nothing to the game as a whole and then just abruptly ends and is gone.- Some puzzles have been simplified to a ridiculously simple level (such as the goat puzzle).- The game is now 100% linear - you can't go to Montfaucon before completing the hospital section, for example.- The diary is a pointless addition and the text within it is far too basic - almost childishly written. It also somehow knows vital plot-related information before these elements have been revealed through dialogue.All in all if you want to rediscover Broken Sword for even play it for the very first time - I simply could never recommend this version of the game. Find a working copy of the original and play that. It's a far superior experience and you won't be missing out on so much material either.

												Years before Dan Brown's Da Vinci's Code made headlines for its religious subject, there was another story that had a similar setting even starting in Paris and ending in Scotland.This gem was Broken Sword: The shadow of the templars a point and click adventure game released 1996 and re-released in 2010 for the PC with more content as Director's Cut.First I'll talk about the main game and after I will talk about the director's cut.The game begins in Paris where our main character George Stobbart is enjoying his vacations.Just as he drinks his coffee and enjoying the Parisian autumn two people enter the Caffe: a man with a briefcase who stops to order a coffee and after a short time a clown with a musical instrument.The clown takes the mans briefcase and leaves his instrument which is revealed to be a bomb which goes off and that's how the game begins.The whole story is about George's quest to find the costume killer, and as the plot advances we find out the whole story arc is about the conflict between Templars and Assassins and the templars called here Neo-Templars are the bad guys(sounds familiar? :) ).Besides Paris, other places you get to visit are Scotland(twice), Spain and Siria, each with its own feel and colorful characters which make this a game a joy to play even after you finished it once.The game has hand-drawn animations which look gorgeous, the voice acting is solid and the music works very well with the whole game.The original game has from me a 10/10 rating, I find no issue with it, its a great adventure game with great characters and a good story.Now about the director's cut, after the success of the first game the game got 4 more sequels: Broken Sword The Smoking Mirror, Broken Sword The Sleeping Dragon, Broken Sword The Angel of Death and recently Broken Sword The Serpents Curse.Between Broken Sword 4 and 5, the first 2 games The Shadow of the Templars and The Smoking Mirror where re-released with more content and improvements.The director's cut of Broken Sword starts with Nicole Collard, not with George a day before the bombing of the caffe and is essentially a prologue setting up the main story.The new content is some levels with Nico where we find more about her past.As the main game starts the first problem appears:the sound quality,the new recordings really stand out against the old ones from the main game,and also some of the character designs look worse than the main game which is weird one good example is when the character visits a hotel in Paris and there is one character reading a newspaper in a armchair, for some reason his outline was removed he looks like a black mass of animation.Also, they changed the interface and added dialogue pics at the top corner of the screen with the faces of the characters with which you hold a conversation.rating for the director's cut: 8/10 the new content is good, but the technical problems really drag down the score, they could have remastered it better, luckily they remastered the second game perfectly and the problems here are not present.

												A valiant attempt at updating a classic, but sadly problematic. I loved this game back in the mid-90s, and couldn't wait to play the new, updated version. But, while they flesh out the character of Nico and expand on her background and personal stake in the investigation (an unnecessary change, but fun), they also seem to have...er...forgotten scenes from the original game. Important scenes. Scenes that move the plot along, explain details of the narrative, etc. Were they omitted? Cut for time? Bugged? EG: In the original, George steps into a hidden alcove in Ireland, and discovers an important clue -- a portrait with an image and a name. But in the Director's Cut George steps into the alcove and then it suddenly cuts back to Nico in Paris; she engages in her own new bit of investigation for a while (completely tangential to the main narrative), and George reappears in Paris not 5 minutes later with only a note in his journal about what he found in the alcove. Why was this changed? What is the purpose of it? They removed a scene CRUCIAL to the main narrative just so they could shoehorn in a mildly interesting superfluous side-story. That could have made a certain narrative sense, it's true, but they didn't alter anything George says or thinks after the scene was cut; he then refers to what he apparently saw as though the player/audience should already have seen it for themselves. Problems like this abound, as do audio hiccoughs -- like when one character is supposed to be speaking, but for no reason the voice-actor of the person they're speaking to is reading their dialogue, complete with the wrong accent and gender! It's bizarre! Did I get some sort of April Fool's Day edition of the game?!?In fact, the more I look at the art and advertising for this updated version, you'd think George was the shoehorned in side-character! All the focus is on Nico, she begins the game, her personal side-narrative takes precedence over the main investigation, and George just comes across as a bumblin' sidekick. It's surreal -- like an alternate universe version of the game I loved. Why not release a separate game or expansion featuring all this new Nico-centric material? It would have saved them the effort of cutting out the old scenes and bugging the audio and video of the game...In any event, i cannot in good conscience recommend the Director's Cut. The Nico side-stories help pad out the game, but come at too high a cost.PS: This game also perpetuates the myth that the Templars were idol-worshipping pagans devoted to Baphomet, a legend which (like "Baphomet") was created during the waves of persecution & torture instituted by the French with papal approval in the 14th century C.E. / A.D. This detail will drive historians and even casual enthusiasts crazy, and miseducate those ignorant of the Templars' history and the Crusades, but it doesn't ruin the game itself. Just be forewarned!

Short version: 90%One of the most well-known point ‘n’ click adventures games from the end of the 90s, Broken Sword is still an enjoyable story almost twenty years later. It may suffer from blocky animation and dreadful voice quality, but the thrilling plot and the quality of the puzzles will always make it a true classic.Long version:Broken Sword: Shadow of the Templars is Revolution Software’s best-known and probably most successful game, known for its sheer length (easily over 12 hours for a first-timer) and good puzzle balance.The story can be described as a modern conspiracy theory thriller featuring an everyday man getting drawn deeper and deeper into the Templar myth, while trying to solve an ancient riddle and staying ahead of his murderous pursuers. To do his he travels all over the world from Ireland to the Middle East, aided by a sassy photojournalist and a bunch of stereotypical, yet cartoonishly entertaining supporting cast.The puzzles are what you expect from a classic adventure game. They are complicated, sometimes convoluted, not too often logical, but if you get yourself in the typical adventure game mind-set, most of them can be passed with little difficulties. (Except the goat. *censored* that goat.)Although Broken Sword features some exceptional backgrounds and decent animation, it is not without technical difficulties. Especially when it comes to audio: most of the dialogue sounds as if it was recorded in an underground chamber, and none of the actors do a particularly good job. Also, in the Remastered Edition there is an additional prologue segment that just does not fit into the game at all.But these are really minor complaints compared to the sheer amount of fun one can have with this classic adventure title that is still one of the best of its kind even to this day.

This director's cut adds a new Section Completely dedicated to Nico, and this alone adds a lot of depth in the story. This section will alternate with George parts giving the game what will be the classic Broken Sword structure that will become a standard in the next chapters, where we play constantly with both George and Nico in separate situations that will later join in a unique context. PUZZLES. There are some nice and interesting puzzles, though I've been really struck by the crypted code puzzles in nico's section. Sounds odd but I really enjoyed those puzzles. PLOT. Maybe the subject doesn't shine with originality but maybe that's because I've played it in 2015. Still its story is nicely structured and has some interesting plot twists.---Cons--- ACTIONS REQUIRE ACTIONS. Even some obvious actions or sections are completely locked unless you observe carefully or talk with some characters first, but maybe it's right this way anyways...

												You know, I like action games, the rush of trying to not die and make through a level, the fear of having to restart your perfect run due to some mistake you made, that feeling you get when you defeat a boss without any potions left, I really enjoy that. But on the other side of the spectrum, I also love puzzle games, and adventure point-and-click games from the 80's and 90's, in my opinion, reign supreme on puzzles. I've been playing them since I was a kid, I've played through the Monkey Islands, the King's Quests, the Space Quests, Grim Fandango, Day of The Tentacle, and several others, and if any of you read my Introduction, you know I'm a big fan of Ben ‘Yahtzee’ Croshaw, but I actually got introduced to his work not through Zero Punctuation, but through 5 Days a Stranger and the Chzo Mythos, back when he used to make adventure games.But still, it's been a long while since I played adventure games, and it is a colossal change of pace from my more recent rogue-like and acti on-based masochism experiences, but I'm glad I'm getting around to try one of the adventure game franchises from the 90's I never got around to play.Broken Sword 1 is a cookie cutter adventure game from 1996, still, almost every game at that time was like that, so not really a criticism. Now, of course most of you know what a adventure game is and how to play it, but I have to drown out these reviews, you know.In said game you point to something to interact with it, either collecting it or gaining some information, and with said items and information, you move forwards through the story. Done, see? I explained it in a short sentence just for you.On a more serious note, I actually really like this game's puzzles, they are mostly well thought out and make sense, Cthulhu knows I've suffered through some badly designed and downright insane puzzles in several adventure games. “BUT SHOES, GOAT PUZZLE MAN, GOAT PUZZLE.” Yes, yes, it's from this game that the infamous goat puzzle was born, I personally didn't find it too bad, but my research told me that it actually makes sense in the Director's Cut (the steam version), so that criticism is basically gone, still, by what I read, that puzzle was just sadistic.The story in this game is really good, it's really gripping and interesting, a bit cliche though, but that is forgivable, most of the characters are really well developed and likable.Nicole Collard, a bold French reporter who got this great interview with one of the national heroes, but when she got to his house, he was murdered by this serial killer she wrote several articles on, The Costume Killer, and after some investigation, she discovered that the murders were all connected to some sort of cult conspiracy, and after writing her paper detailing all that, she received a phone call from her boss ordering her to stop writing and never talk about this business again, until a mysterious phone call directed her to meet a man in a café.George Stobbart, an American touring through France found himself enjoying some latte in a café, until he noticed a strange and suspicious man entering said café, he paid no mind to it, but after a while a clown with an accordion rushed inside the café and left without his accordion, but a briefcase, the same briefcase the man was carrying, and after a while… EXPLOSION!!! The whole place was blown to smithereens, and so George feels it's his civilian duty to find this killer clown and help the authorities, until he met pretty reporter Nicole, who told him about the whole conspiracy. And so, together they must find this assassin and put a end to this madness.The writing is pretty good, I give the game that, and there is a quite nice bit of mystery and intrigue, as well as some well done twists, it's a pretty enjoyable ride.The graphical design is well done, the cutscenes are really well drawn, downright breathtaking at times, they also somewhat remind me of the Don Bluth cartoons, which I really enjoyed. That said, the in-game graphics looks kind of odd, the backgrounds are nice, but the characters seem a bit off, I can't really tell what it is, but still, not bad at all, considering when this game was made. The music on the other hand is really good, it gives the vibe of mystery and conspiracy, it really is ear candy. Back to the other hand though, the voice acting has some issues, and it really is noticeable, not experience-ruining, but still, you can clearly notice when they used different microphones and when they recorded on different locations, because at times the voices sound really good, at others it's just awful, but it isn't on the actor's fault, they do mostly a good job, a bit cringeworthy at times, but nothing too bad, the problem really is the microphone. 1996 though, so I'll give it a pass.Overall, the game is great, I definitively recommend it, it's a well done adventure game, the experience is definitively worth the time. It's got good characters, a good story, and good design, if you're a adventure aficionado you've already played this, so I don't know why I even brought that up.DEUS VULT!

In the first episode you'll investigate murders linked to a very uncommon murderer as a female reporter called Nico Collard. She will though need the help of some other people including George Stobbart an American tourist who will be involved the first day of his holidays in Paris. 												Broken Sword and Broken Sword 2 are two of the greatest adventure games of all time. They are rightfully up there with the Lucasarts masterpieces such as Monkey Island, Day of the Tentacle, Grim Fandango, and Indiana Jones and the Fate of Atlantis. But the one thing that BS had in its favour that in some aspects elevated it above those games was the incredibly immersive and detailed story. The story was originally like The Da Vinci Code, before it was even a thing; rich, complex and based on history. It also had great, humourous dialogue, and the exploring element once more elevated it. You could pretty much look at anything, try using anything, and the game never held your hand in terms of completeing puzzles, making for a truly challenging game, in which a wrong move could have your character killed.Broken Sword: Directors Cut has stripped back virtually all the things that made the original great. As someone who has played the original literally dozens of times, I knew from the opening sequence that something was wrong. I don't mind that they have interspersed a couple of new puzzles into the game, but the new animation is jarring and horribly static flash animation, as opposed to the original Disney-esque fluid cinematics from the original. But I quickly noticed that the cafe scene (which opens the original game) is missing a lot of things that I used to love looking at, and getting George's cynical or funny takes on. The dialogue has been halved, the puzzles have been halved, and its just a big mess. Some of the dialogue has been re-recorded for some reason, which is painfully obvious from a striking difference in audio quality.I seriously love BS, but i feel like i paid for a DC and ended up with a Broken Sword: Lite instead. Remember when Monkey Island 2 first came out, and there was an option to play it with easier puzzles? This is basically that, but without the option of the full experience. Is there an original version of this on Steam? If so, i'd go for that.EDIT: I've just been informed that the version on GOG.com comes with the option to play the original or the DC, so i would suggest getting that. 												A thrilling, good written classic point and click-adventure with some "deepness and seriousness" i miss from other adventures today.The game starts with an assassination in a cafe in Paris, where the american George Stobbart unfortunately decided to chill on his travel. He survives it, and starts together with a female journalist, Nicole Collard, to investigate about the assassin. The more they find out about it, the more they get involved into a thrilling, murderous Story about the old temple knights, assassins and a secret society.The original version of this game from 1996 is one of my favourite point and click-adventures, unfortunately only the Director's Cut-Version  is available on steam. The DC-Version got new content included (1-2hours of story and riddles with Nico) and a help system. "It got new content, and still you like the original version more, why?" you ask ? Here is why:- new content doesn't fit in (new graphics mixed with the old graphics, same with the audio)- content got cut out from the original version: Scenes where you can die are cut out; dialogues who are not fitting for children; some hotspots are not clickable anymore.That takes a huge portion of the thrill and entertainment away from me.Any way, one of the best point and click-adventures that you should have played, if you like the genre. But better get the original version!

												Ah, Broken Sword. I have heard a lot about this series as the years passed and now I had the opportunity to play it myself. Normally not a fan of point and click adventures I have to say that given the age and history of the game I really like it. Some cliché story elements to be sure but what really struck me was how incredibly witty this game can be. I have too many scenes to quote that if I would merely start I would quickly fill several pages worth.The puzzles also stood out for me. Decoding messages and moving puzzles around in a fashion that I have, to my great disappointed realization, never encountered in any form in any modern game. The puzzles are simplistic in nature but brilliant in execution and are genuinely tricky even for a puzzle veteran like myself.The hints system is a gem for people prone to getting stuck. It levels small suggestions to more direct hints to giving you the solution outright if you as for enough hints.The story is nice but in this day and age it's not very original. For me it's the journey to the end that makes the fun part of this brilliant game. The side characters you encounter are most memorable in my opinion. English ladies, Spanish aristocrats, French police officers.I only really have two complaints about this game. The ending is a liiittle anticlimactic. but my #1 main issue is when switching areas and watching the characters walking around is sooo slooow and gets old very rapidly.I closing I would very much recommend Broken Sword: Shadow of the Templars to friends of classics, puzzles and adventure. I hope you have fun playing. ^_^

												There's a surprising amount of modern sensibility to this remake of the original Broken Sword.  There's a helpful hint system, interactive objects flash with a small icon, and there are the usual visual and audio upgrades you'd expect.  You'll still run into some infuriating moments of classic adventure game puzzledom, but the hint system is fairly clear and the pixel hunting is, thankfully, kept to a minimum.  The hand-drawn graphics look sharp, but sometimes the speech seems slightly off, as though some dialogue was spliced in using different equipment.  It can be a bit jarring.  For the most part, though, this is a serviceable remake of a classic adventure game, and the story is still a fun little mystery romp.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												George and Nicole hold a special place in my young life as the harbingers of a new type of adventure gaming for me.  When I first clicked the game disc into the drive to play, it was the first time I would play an adventure game on a console (PlayStation) and it was a distinct shift in the style of adventure gaming I had played up to that point.The year was 1996 and I had grown up through the golden age of adventure games; Monkey Island, Indiana Jones, Day of the Tentacle, Full Throttle and Space Quest had all been my staple gaming for many years on the good ol' Amiga! Little did I know at the time but these had all tuned my thinking into a zany, wacky and ultimately illogical thought process where (spoilers!!!) rubber chickens could be used on zip lines, cocktail chemistry is the key to thickening your loogey to win a spitting competition and little lizards ate cheetos.So when I first played Broken Sword, not only was it a novelty to be playing a classic point and click style adventure with a controller on a console (which worked damn well and something we now take for granted), but I was quite regularly stumped by what were quite 'normal' and logical puzzles.  I just couldn't figure them out.There was no plethora of random objects in my inventory to be combined in some obscure way.  Puzzles didn't require a tongue in cheek reworking of cultural tropes and there weren't any in-game phone boxes to call a puzzle help line.  Such is the indelible mark left by this style of the 90s classics upon adventure games that this brand of zaniness has become synonymous with the entire genre.  That's not to say Broken Sword was devoid of wit or charm, quite the opposite.  Not only was the plot brilliant with plenty of depth and twists but the dialogue and inner monologues were sharp and witty too.  The late writer, Dave Cummins, was responsible for much of this humour that still brings out a chuckle in me today.  Here's just a taste of some of the zingers:George: I felt a slight twinge of conscience as I prepared to give the dog a dunking. It soon passed.George: He had the eyes of a cocker-spaniel set in a face like a deflated soufflé.George: You speak very good English for a French girl.Nicole: Thanks. You speak very good English for an American.Jarring at first, I did eventually become accustomed to an adventure set more in reality than not and discovered a new, different and deeper appreciation of the genre.  With Broken Sword, I was gripped by the story and two protagonists who drew me in through a novel-like tale of historical intrigue, deception and an awkward romance.  From the very first almost cliche Parisienne scene I was gripped by the entirety of what was on offer.The art style is iconic which, coupled with the fantastic music, creates a strong ambience throughout with many memorable scenes and moments.  The writing is fantastic with dry humour and an awkwardness that characterises George so perfectly.  This compliments and contrasts so well with the intelligent, chic and curious Nico that by the end of the game, we are left with a compelling duo with whom we wish we could spend more time and indeed has provided the foundation of four sequels.  The puzzles are solid head scratchers for the most part (Irish goats excluded!) and tie in neatly with the story they don't break the continuity or mood which is common in the less thoughtful offerings of the adventure genre.When the Director's Cut was released on Steam years later in 2009, it was an instant buy for me.  The little changes made, such as being able to play as Nico at certain points and the addition of some new puzzles, outweighed the simplification of others.  It's a brilliant polishing up of a classic that was so deserving of its commercial and critical acclaim that launched a series and gave us George and Nico.This is a review from my website:  https://wingedtankard.wordpress.com/2017/02/02/broken-sword-shadow-of-the-templars-directors-cut/

Discovered:Nothing beats a game with a good story and voice acting.Good/Bad:It was interesting for me to experience a classic such as this. Most of the excitement can be found within the exchange of words and simple actions of cause and effect throughout the game. Each person you meet is as lively and memorable as they can be. The script, minus the voice acting suffering from bad recording, is one of the elements that make this an unforgettable gaming experience.One problem I found myself wrestling with is that it isn’t clear as to what needs to be done next. It is a blessing that there is a  hint system in place. It’s more about discovering something by looking at it then talking to a person and then the person gives information that opens up another conversation to another person somewhere else or opens up a new location to go to next... uhm… I guess I just literally described the adventure genre! I suppose this complaint exists because of me not paying attention to the details of everything happening in the game. My bad! No matter, it was an amazing game, nevertheless.Update: Having seen what the game used to be on Youtube, I was shocked at the amount of original content that was cut from the game! Apparently there were multiple branching choices that led to death sequences and other story content that were cut out. Summary:Director’s Cut Broken Sword has all the pieces that make a great game. Although some of those pieces are worn out and missing, it is still able to keep the player engaged through its smart dialogue and unfolding story. Just be sure to always remember to “point, click, listen & repeat”.Last Thoughts: Definitely for adventure fans who love a good old fashioned story over anything. The humor was smart and made me laugh a couple of times which was great because not a lot of games can get that out of me. I can’t wait to play the sequels!

												I'm writing this review for people who, like me, might look into this game hoping for an adventure game with a decent female lead, or at least co-lead. Spoilers: you're not going to find it in this game.Gameplay-wise: Speaking as a person who only encountered Broken Sword recently and thus in its newest version only, I found the game passably engaging. The puzzles do make you think and offer a large range of potential combinations, although there are places where it drags because the game expects you to do something completely counter-intuitive and gives no feedback on whether you're doing it right, so you go through every single item and combination thereof, then dialogue choices, and finally click everything before you hit it. The hint system might as well not have existed, since it didn't help me and apparently annoyed previous lovers of the game. The graphics are what you might expect from a decade old game, not really updated but not too terrible.[Some spoilers] As for the characters, you play as Nico Marlet, who is a fairly decent character, drawn into the murder of her newest interviewee and subsequent meddling into her life, for about 30 minutes out of a 7 hour playthrough. The rest of the time you play as George Stubbart, whose only connection to the whole affair was he happened to be at a cafe when it blew up to kill the man inside, and decided he had to solve the crime for great justice or something. He takes center stage and then keeps it for the rest of the game while Nico sits at her apartment and waits, or seduces someone over the phone, or talks to an archaelogist friend to create a really gross doubly-oneside love triangle centered around her. Also there is a very dubious (consent-wise) scene later in the game between George and Nico, whose romance doesn't really have any substance beyond George thinking she's pretty a few times? So many things seem shoehorned in without proper support. It's both baffling and irritating. If you want a decent head-scratcher and don't mind a host of gender issues, then pick this up. If you wanted a game which treats its women respectfully, don't do what I did. Buy another game.

												Unfortunately this isn't a game I would want to play again anytime soon. As I have understood, a lot of original content was cut from the game and replaced to make the game more storydriven as well as helping you along the way to solve things a.k.a handholding. ~ Good ~Graphics: I think they are beautiful for its time. The animation is extremely smooth, the characters move realistic and at times it's hard to think they are built out of simple pixels. The backgrounds are all well detailed and even the background characters have solid animation. Voice acting:It's quite obvious some of the voices were re-recorded and others are still old. Sometimes it will sound like someone is sitting in an empty room, with a slight echoing sound to it. Other times you hear that the sounds are clearer. The english voiceacting is fine. Nicole has a lovely voice, but I honestly can't understand a thing she says without subtitles. She has a very thick french accent, so it isn't the fault of the game. Characters:I found that the background characters bring most of the fun to the game. Some of them are very weird in a quirky way (the kebab seller) and they are the ones responsible for the funny dialogue. Between the boring story, it was fun to hang around and talk to these characters. I wish there had been more of this and less about the Templars. ~ Bad ~Story:I honestly found this one boring, hence why I am reluctant to play it again. I think it was a bad thing to give the story so much focus. As you are mostly trying to find information about it, all you do is listen to people talk, talk, talk, talk, talk... ugh. The ending was also grossly dissapointing. Imagine spending hours upon hours trying to find this one final part and it's not even half of what it was hyped up to be. Dialogue heavy: This game relies heavily on you listening to conversations and if you don't snap up the important parts, you are going to have hell trying to solve some of the puzzles. A lot of the dialogue feels repeatetive as you are asking about the very same thing. The “oh so myserious” Templars and everyones opinion on it. Soundtrack: I found all the music out of place and some of the special effect sounds got on my nerve. Whenever the characters are experiencing a happy moment, the cheesiest of tunes plays in the background. The music also seems extremely loud compared to the voice acting. I keep the music at 20% and the voices at 100%, yet I still find that cheesy tune overpowering some of the conversations. Whenever you try to use an object on an area which you'll be able to use an item at some point, a glittering sound is played. I am guessing to help the player find clues, but it becomes extremely distracting and tedious, especially when you have 10 items to try. There's also short tunes playing anytime the characters make a conclusion to something, which also gets quite cheesy after a while. Despite these obvious hints, I found the game wasn't clear at all as to what it wanted you to do. Your only kind of help is a question mark that pretty much repeats the very same question you have, without giving any hints at how to solve the problem. Lack of interactions:There really doesn't happen much in the game besides dialogue. Most of the puzzles are solved by listening to dialogue or showing the right item for more dialogue. Sometimes the only way to advance the story is talking to everyone in a different order to get the information you need. And the sad things is, the dialogue about the story is the most boring part of the game. I only had fun when I was allowed to use items in the environment to solve things, or try to figure out how to get past guards without them taking an item from me. Dialogue is 90% of the game and the rest is some puzzle solving. Awful minigames:The first minigame involves solving a cypted message, which contains at least 2 names which you have heard maybe once or twice throughout the gameplay. Another terrible minigames involves you having to put roman numbers in order of a message, then click a button, then order them correctly again. All in a specific order. And what happens if you mess up 7/8? The whole puzzle resets and you have to do it all over again! Ugh! And the numbers move slow.Removed content:This game has obviously been censured by removing the death scenarios. There was supposed to be a timed action scene with a deadly outcome, but instead George will automatically solve the problem for you. So much for suspense? It's also dissapointing that once you solve one of the bigger mysteries, the screen just cuts and all you get is George words about what it was. Appearently he picks up an item from a room, but seeing him do so is completely removed, as is everything he does and sees in the room. And this is after solving the tedious roman puzzle! Way to go rewarding the player by removing one of the most important scenes after forcing them through the worst minigame.

												If you're a fan of the original Broken Sword, then, as you can probably tell from the other reviews... This is, by and large, a safe bet for a great gameAs a newcomer though... I'm not entirely bowled overDone right, point-and-click can be brilliant. Certainly, the start of the game is very engaging. You're exploring places for useful / hidden items and trying to work out how to piece them all together. It's not long before you're given some challenging but great puzzles to solve too (the door lock and the decryption of the letter) - The characters are also quickly likeable, and George's charm in fumbling around Paris is certainly endearing. The game also packs a lot more humour than you'd expect - And I confess I garnered probably too much amusement from showing people soiled tissues, drain-openers and desperately trying to make them shake my handSo why the thumbs down?After the quick-draw of puzzles at the start, they almost seemed to dry up. The 'thinking' puzzles largely became talking to people in the correct order or showing them a certain item to trigger an event... which then required you to talk to yet more people. Whilst the reactions were fresh and entertaining to begin with, I admit I started getting impatient half way through the game and sometimes skipped through the unimportant dialogue or George telling me the item was not suitable - my heart sank a bit when I walked into a pub of about 5-6 characters... all to talk to, all with around 6-8 potential dialgues (based upon the item I show them). It started becoming a lot of sitting around and wasn't massaging my cerebral matter very muchYour actions also don't really seem to amount to much. You have a few 'options' in dialogue, but where they seem to garner the same results, it felt a bit pointless. You can't exactly seem to do things "wrong", and it's sometimes just trial and error (and clicking) until you find the right one. In effect, you find you're not quite exploring the game, but just fumbling around until you can find the plot trail it ultimately had prepared for you. It basically started feeling like less of a game and more that I was slowly clicking my way through a filmIt was engaging enough to see me through to the end, for sure - though a tad anti-climactic. The graphics were delightful (nicely remastered without too many elements where the old pixellated style was evident) and voice acting great... but it just didn't do it for me

												Broken Sword: Shadow of the Templars was an awesome murder-mystery themed romp throughout the streets of Paris and all around Europe. I loved the way it combined narrative, character development and puzzle solving into a game that was consistently interesting, and fun to beat.I was genuinely challenged by the puzzles at certain stages, whereas others were simpler than I thought (don't get me started on that roman numeral one). Whenever I got truly stumped, however, the game stepped in with its handy hint system. I like that the first hint never gave too much away, it was a step in the right direction without showing you exactly how to get there - I rarely needed to go any further than that.As for the characters: I love Nico. I think she's brilliant. I like her accent, her smarts, her characterisation, and the way she takes the blows dealt to her in the storyline; I especially like that we start the game out as her, that she has her own personal ties to the story that she doesn't let anyone else know, and that she doesn't fall for George's charms until he proves himself.Speaking of George, I liked how he is the polar opposite of Nico. She's all poise and calculation, whereas he is spontaneity and humour. Some of the things you could make him say or do were very entertaining, and I like that they went there with it. My only gripe with George and his part in the story is that he seemed to dominate it! It was disappointing that Nico, who was set up to be the primary storyteller in this game, had become a side-character of her own story and, by the end of it, fell into place as a love interest for George and the typical damsel in distress he needed to save. On the flip side, it was also a tad demeaning to poor George that he had to spend all his time travelling places to solve a mystery he'd all but stumbled upon, doing all the leg work, while Nico chilled in her apartment in Paris. (Double standards, amirite?)All my venting aside, while not spending more time in Nico's shoes was disappointing, it didn't ruin the game for me, not by a long shot. After all, who you walk around as doesn't matter all that much when it comes to the plot, and the plot of Broken Sword is incredibly compelling. I won't go into the details - apart from saying: PLAY IT - but I remained on the edge of my seat for the most part. There were a few times where the game lulled, but if it didn't, I'd be on the computer for nine hours straight. I'll wind up this long-winded review by saying that this was a great game, and I'm really looking forward to playing the second one. I'm hoping there's more Nico - and that George does return, as despite my complaining earlier I really do like him - and another mystery to solve!

												There was a popular article by Old Man Murray which used Gabriel Knight 3 as an example for the kind of nonsensical, ridiculously contrived puzzles that killed adventure games. This point & click classic is an excellent counterargument. With its high production values, interesting - if slightly cliched - story, fun characters and good puzzles, it's a reminder of why many of us enjoy adventure games.The puzzles only get frustratingly difficult in one or two places, but the solutions are always logical and with not an onerous amount of try-everything-with-everything-else tedium. Sometimes solutions to later problems are hinted at elsewhere, so it really helps to pay attention. The voice acting is great for such an old game, though recorded a little unevenly. Play with subtitles so you don't miss anything.There are a few bugs in the Linux/Steam version I played - mostly to do with skipping during cutscenes. Having now finished the game I don't feel I missed anything though.Looking forward to getting to the rest of the series.

												This game is a point and click detective style game.  If you are looking for a more interactive game, this isn't for you.  This game is about deductive reasoning and puzzle solving.  I would say my overall experience is that it started off very strong--puzzles were difficult to solve, the next step wasn't always obvious but would take some time to figure out, and the story/dialogue was entertaining.  As the game went on, I found the game to lose some of its earlier greatness.  The actual puzzles were few and far between and it became less intuitive to figure out what you had to do.  Some of the things you had to do were downright stupid and made no sense--one puzzle essentially makes you enter a set of numbers by tediously turning a wheel and pressing a button, and if you don't get every number right you have to start over again.  If you try to go through the game without using hints, you end up using an oldschool RPG approach, procedurally asking every person about every piece of evidence you have and trying to use every piece of evidence on any interactive element in the game, which simply isn't fun.  In about the last 15 minutes of the game they force a romance on the player between the very likeable French girl and the totally unlikeable American idiot who you are forced to play as for about 3/4 of the game.  Also, the animations in the cutscenes are pretty bad.  In summation, I found this game to be enjoyable some of the time--I do enjoy puzzles in which critical thinking is required, but it fell flat as far as plot, immersion, and consistent novelty.   I'd give it about a 4/10--it had a few funny jokes in there.  Most were cringe worthy, but a few landed.

												It must have been nearly twenty years since I've played the original Broken Sword for the very first time. Literally this has been the big bang of my adventure love, the origin where everything started, encouraging me to play a nearly countless number of point-and-click games up to the present day. The more it hurts to give a negative review. My criticism concerns the Director's Cut and not the original version of the game, which - while never reaching the quality of the very best LucasArts games - can be considered a classic and should be played at least once by every serious adventure player. For being superior Broken Sword suffers a bit too much from its dull stereotypes and jokes at the expense of others for my taste. That aside it is a good game and a staple of the genre.What flips my review from blue to red are the changes the publisher did in the Director's Cut. For sure I've read other negative reviews regarding these changes beforehand, nevertheless I decided to give this version a try, thinking it can't be that bad. I was wrong. Well, it is always difficult to replay a childhood game, the risk of breaking the rose-colored glasses is nearly hard-wired, but it has not been the game itself that spoiled my experience. No, it rather happened that I felt in love again with all the things I enjoyed in the past and felt familiar with. It's the deviations from these familiar things that broke the magic and in all honesty and objectivity, none of the changes Revolution Software did in the Director's Cut does the game any good. If I want to say at least something positive I would say that the added portraits partly feel felicitous. On the other hand these additions don't fit the graphical stlyle of the game and are as redundant as all the other changes in the Director's Cut. I've been prepared to worry about the new mandatory mouse-over hotspot 'feature', which is a pile of junk treating me like a moron, unable to solve anything on my own (other recent games provide keybinds to enable/disable hotspots) but it is far more than that. The whole new Nico chapter is redundant, feels out of place and adds nothing interesting to the game. Even worse this chapter replaces the phenomenal flight over paris intro from the original game. Furthermore there are a lot less hotspots and hence less comments in the game, making it super simple and less intriguing. The famous goat puzzle is totally ruined (in the past solving this puzzle was somehow special - even for new players it is 2 seconds now), same as every single scene where your character was able to die in the original game. You simply can't die any longer and every option that would have lead to death has been removed without substitution. And the final cutscene... come on guys, nobody needs that.I'm not dissapointed because my childhood game has been changed somehow. I'm dissapointed because my childhood game has been changed somehow in a bad way and it's messed now. It would have been way better if the puplisher just had rereleased the original game as it is. Verdict. My whole playthrough was a rollercoaster of cozy memories and extremely bad 'OMG, what have they done?' moments. Nevertheless even this Director's Cut sprays some Broken Sword charme. So if you've never played the game or if you've played the original game without having close affiliations with it, it might be ok to play this version with scaled down expectations. However if you've played the original game in the past and felt in love with it, avoid this version by all means.9/10 (original game, released 1996)5/10 (Director's Cut)

												First of all: I can't recommend this version of the game unless it's to someone who wants an easy handheld walkthrough (and doesn't mind jarring main character switches and even more jarring character voice changes). I'd recently gotten back into adventure games (after having grown up playing Sierra and Lucasarts games in the 80s & 90s). Saw this one listed on a couple of top adventure game lists; thought I'd give it a try. The game begins with our intrepid heroine Nico going to meet with some high-fallutin' Parisien media mogul only to witness his murder. First thing I noticed when I got control of the character? That blue flashing light that indicates things the character can interact with. Helpful at first, but later an annoyance when I realized I was searching the screens for the blue light instead of actually looking at what was on the screen. Really annoyed when I realized there was no way to turn it off. So I stumbled from place to place with Nico, equally despising and yearning for that blue light, occasionally solving mildly difficult logic puzzles made even easier by the detailed instructions that left me wondering if this coupled with the blue light meant the game considered me some sort of idiot who couldn't figure things out on my own. (I'm playing Broken Sword after having just completed Black Mirror, which gave no instructions on how to solve its puzzles - and therefore left me feeling more satisfied when I did solve them.) Then suddenly I'm controlling George, an American lawyer who witnesses another murder and even though he has nothing to do with the murder or the case, he decides to get involved. I'm still unsure on his motivations for that (or why that workman didn't stop what he was doing to come help after the bombing! The dude was RIGHT THERE and never put down his shovel... Egads...) Anyway, the two characters decide to share info, even though so far as I can tell Nico's the only one who has anything invested in all this. From then on the playable character switches back and forth, often when I'm not ready for it (I thought I had more to investigate! Which I guess means I did all the stuff required to move on already...?). And sometimes the game takes me to the next location I need to go instead of letting me figure out where to go next.  I saved my game after playing somewhere in the range of two hours and saw my progress was 25% through the game. That really bummed me out. This was way too fast and too easy. Again, I grew up on adventure games in a pre-internet world. Sometimes I'd get stuck and it'd take weeks or months before I or my brother would have an epiphany and discover what we had to do next. This plays like it's meant to be rushed through in an afternoon, perhaps by people who don't want to stretch their brains too much. So I did a bit of research and discovered this version - the Director's Cut - is actually quite different from the original, in which you only play George (the guy who - so far - has no reason to be involved in this story?!) and there's no blue light and you can die and, ARGH why can't I play that version?!  Well, apparently I can. Now I'll just have to wait for it to go on sale on the other site. Bummer. After I finish Original Flavor, I'll come back and try this one again. The graphics and animations are just fine. So is the voice-work, except for when suddenly someone else is voicing the main character and trying to imitate the original, or certain lines of dialogue sound like they were recorded in a wind tunnel. Also annoying is having to sit there and watch two characters have a telepathic conversation (their mouths don't move), though I have encountered that in other games I've played, and I suppose the animations would be a pain, especially considering the amount of languages this game was made for. I can't really say much about the story so far as I've barely delved into it. The whole thing is giving me a Gabriel Knight vibe (which is a good thing!) except not as dark (literally). But I love Templar history and mysteries so hopefully the story turns out to be groovy (and I can recommend this game after getting my hands on the original). One super-annoyance that I have to point out: past tense. Past tense! Why is everything the characters narrate in the present in past tense?! 'It was a brandy bottle.' Why not: 'It IS a brandy bottle'? And then the 'show-vs-tell' sin of having the characters explicitly state how they feel about something. When faced with entering a sewer, Nico says: 'There might have been clues down there. I was relieved I didn't have a key.' Instead, have the actress 'show' how Nico feels through her line reading of: 'There might be clues down there. But thank goodness I don't have a key.' Except for the too on-the-nose recicitation of their feelings, it sounds like something Humphrey Bogart would narrate in one of his Sam Spade films. It just doesn't work for me here.

												So, what can you say about a game that is widely regarded as one of the great classics of adventure games? A game that is often among the top five of various best-of-lists? A game that is held dear by many a gamer around the world? A game that already has been drowned in gallons of words over the decades?Well, I can say I finished it, I guess... And I can say that I'm having a hard time understanding why Broken Sword is so highly regarded by so many people nowadays. Let me clarify my history with this game though because maybe that'll illuminate my lack of enthusiasm. I did not play it back in 1996 when it was released, nor did I play it in 2009 when the Director's Cut was released for Nintendo consoles or in 2010 when it was released for PC/Mac. No, I played it in September 2013 without any prior knowledge. Now, I'm an old man and I enjoy a Werther's Original as much as the next old geezer, so I generally don't have problems with older games for pure technical or gameplay reasons, as they're the games I grew up playing. And yeah, the graphics are fine, the music is fine, the animations are fine, the sound quality is mostly decent, the controls are fine and whatever else is fine. The puzzles are mostly above average, the voice acting is quite alright and the UI doesn't make me want to vomit.The problems, for me, are the dialogs, the story and the characters. The dialogs are just not funny. Not at all. But they're clearly meant to be funny, which makes it cringeworthy. George is amassing all his wit in every interaction and let's lose some quip that is just so out of place. It's not only not funny, it's also not tied into the conversation, so he comes across like some♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥who constantly interrupts the people he starts to talk to with random and oftentimes even mean sentences. It's really enervating and you start to ask yourself why do these people keep talking to him...The story on the other hand is kinda meandering from some place to the next and then in the end George literally tells us out of nowhere what it is all about and I wondered how the ♥♥♥♥ he knew that... It's really badly written, which is surprising considering that Broken Sword was always lauded for the writing.And lastly, at least to me, the George and Nico dynamic just isn't there yet. It gets way better in Broken Sword 2 and especially 3 but in this game they just don't really click, imho. Again, it's really weird since the characters were highly praised back in the day. According to Wikipedia and Mobygames.So apparently the Director's Cut cuts a lot of content in dialogs, puzzles and areas that was originally in the game. I don't know, maybe the game is really, really cool with intact dialogs and story and the original version deserves its place among the greats but this here does not. Or maybe it is just one of the games that has sooooo horribly aged that nothing of its former glory is left. Like GoldenEye 007 for the N64 or WarCraft 2...It's worth to buy in a 75% sale just to play one of the classics but you're probably better of buying it from GoG where you get the Director's Cut and the original Version together.

												As  the title suggests, there is more content then the original game. Not much more, save for an intro sequence where you play as Nico, that has been added for a bit of extra gameplay, This isn’t bad as it sets the scene well.There are however, some seriously lazy things to behold here, Perhaps the most in your face of these is the voice quality. As far as I can tell, the sound files have been ported from the original game, and are very low quality in places.The Voice acting is a bit hit and miss I have to say. Some of them forget which accent they are supposed to be using for their assigned character, which is actually at times more accidentally comical than anything else.The game has quite a few places to go, and things to see, and all are very well realized. The game will take you from France to South America, to The Middle East, to the UK. You will also encounter quite a large number of interesting people along the way, with some truly memorable dialogue.For the bulk of the game you play as George, who is very well voice acted whereas Nico unfortunately has a voice actress who falls into the inconsistent accent category. This however is not enough to take away from how cool the character is.There is one major fall that the game takes. and that is in some of its overly elaborate puzzles. Some of which are too abstract, and as a result can make the game become rather boring. I reached a point where I simply couldn’t be bothered any more.Over all, the game is good, well written and it has a nice colorful art direction, but should you wish to try this one, be ready for frustration and a degree of boredom

Posted: July 13, 2015
												“What does this tissue mean to you?”Broken Sword: Director’s Cut is a pleasant and traditional point and click adventure. It has a typical inventory system with the ability to combine items to solve puzzles and modify the environment to progress through the game. The puzzles are challenging but nothing hardcore at all. I was able to get through the game only using the hint system twice and it was only to confirm I was trying to do the correct thing after feeling stuck. The dialog is ok and read at a good pace for the different characters. The voice acting is not the best. It varies in tone and volume, sometimes from one line to the next. I can’t be too critical as this is an older game. The story starts out as a murder mystery but quickly evolves into something bigger that you uncover. The only gripe is the pacing felt uneven and really accelerated towards the end. I was caught off guard when the game ended. Pros+Classic click and point adventure style+Puzzles are not overly challenging (personal preference)+Lots of characters you interact with+Manual save system+Environments are drawn nicelyCons+Uneven pacing of story+Abrupt end+Iffy voice acting and overall quality of voice+Almost too much hand holding6/10 Above averageBroken Sword has an interesting story combined with challenging yet manageable puzzles. Solid inventory, notes system and a variety of locations you visit on your journey. The seemingly abrupt ending is a bit disheartening but doesn’t detract from an otherwise traditional click and point adventure game. If you are a fan of point and click, grab this on a sale.

												Broken Sword is a fantastic game, and the director's cut edition certainly attempts to improve upon it, but some of the attempts come over as rather half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and not well thought of.GameplayThe game plays like a typical point & click adventure game. You search for objects and interaction points in the environment that the objects can interact with. Unfortunately, the object interaction is rather two-dimensional. Where monkey island used verbs (e.g., 'use X on Y', 'look at X', 'push X', 'pull X', 'talk to X', 'open X', 'close X', 'talk to X'), the interface of Broken Sword is very much simplified. A left click performs the main action on a target, while a right click inspects the target. The main interaction is whatever the game deems you should do to the target. A door gets opened, a person gets spoken to, a button gets pushed. This removes a bunch of interactions, while streamlining the gaming process. Furthermore, it makes it very easy to just try out every object on every target if you are stuck. Five objects on 1 target result in 5 actions, yet 9 verbs for 5 objects on 1 target results in 45 actions, forcing you to think rather than just to try.The gameplay in the DC edition has been further simplified. For instance, actions cannot lead to player death anymore. Instead, the character will inform you that what you're about to do is definitely not a good idea. Objects are highlighted on the screen, so they're very easy to find. While carefully examining the screen makes you think about what objects would be interesting to inspect, highlighting the objects removes this entirely. While it can be cumbersome, I personally feel it is part of the game and do not consider this an improvement. At the very least, this should have been an optional setting we could enable or disable.Hints are certainly a good addition to the game. Nowadays with the easy access to walkthroughs, the temptation is too large to just ruin the game for yourself if you really get stuck (it keeps getting easier and easier to resort to a walkthrough). Hints will help you out, but still make you think. This is an excellent solution to the widespread availability of walkthroughs.Talking to NPCs in the game is done by using avatars/player faces (or however you want to call it). I'm not a big fan of those, as I prefer the old method where text was displayed above the character in a distinct color. This is probably just nostalgia speaking, though, so I can hardly blame the devs for making this alteration.More ContentThe DC edition has more scenes than the original, and that's fantastic. Unfortunately, it seems not all of those scenes are voiced by the same characters and at the same audio quality. In some cases this is really noticable, even without a good set of headphones. The extra scenes are very welcome, though, especially if you are a big fan of the series. It just feels like the developer either did not know how to prevent inconsistencies with the content (e.g., different graphical styles that clash, and audio quality and voice differences) or approached it in a very half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥way.ConclusionWhile the game is worth the asking price, I'm drawn on whether I would recommend the director's cut edition or the original. The DC edition has the advantage of being on the steam platform and having extra content, but it also adds some aspects you simply cannot disable that diminish the gaming experience.As a result I will recommend this game only because the original is not steam. It is a shame, though, that they did not allow you to switch between the original and the DC edition in the settings. In that case, the game would have gotten a more certain recommendation from me, and most of the criticism would be trivial.

Unfortunately I became bored about 1/3 of the way through and chugging through any of the remaining locations became a complete chore.A lot of people would apparently disagree with me but I feel like there must be a nostalgia factor that I'm missing out on. Objectively speaking, this game would have been fantastic to experience in 1996. Plenty of witty banter and dialogue, and fluidly animated cutscenes. It's damn impressive how much animation is provided for random interactions that don't even advance the story in any way.But that's sort of the problem. At first it's not a big deal- there are a few characters to interact with, and a few items in your inventory. It's neat to experience the combination of interactions. Until both categories grow larger and you suddently have to start asking every single person about every single item. Some interactions are over quickly, some take minutes to complete as the NPC tells you something inane. Speeding through interactions can become clunky as you watch your character stumble around the screen with their pathfinding alorithm only to show up at their destination and shrug their shoulders, a way of telling the player 'nope, that won't work.' Fine, but you could have just said that to begin with.I was absolutely shocked to find out that apparently this Director's cut had substantial sections of dialogue missing. With each syllable of spoken dialogue I pray that the game takes mercy on me and makes it the last. And you guys wanted MORE?You might argue that the superfluous dialogue is optional. You don't have to ask everyone about everything. Well, sometimes you do. Sometimes when the puzzle solutions are completely arbitrary you'll wander around for ages in hopes of obtaining a relevant clue, only to find that you forgot to use that one item on that one thing that gives you that one other thing. Because why wouldn't you need that one thing. Of course you need to take a tissue full of facepaint all the way to syria, to polish a statue, to sell to a tourist, to get fifty dollars, to buy a cab ride. Never mind that you've been eating, living, and travelling for days on your own budget. THE GAME HAS DECIDED THAT THIS IS CURRENTLY THE ONLY WAY TO OBTAIN THING YOU WANT.You might also argue that I have a short attention span. 												Broken Sword is a fantastic game, and the director's cut edition certainly attempts to improve upon it, but some of the attempts come over as rather half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and not well thought of.GameplayThe game plays like a typical point & click adventure game. You search for objects and interaction points in the environment that the objects can interact with. Unfortunately, the object interaction is rather two-dimensional. Where monkey island used verbs (e.g., 'use X on Y', 'look at X', 'push X', 'pull X', 'talk to X', 'open X', 'close X', 'talk to X'), the interface of Broken Sword is very much simplified. A left click performs the main action on a target, while a right click inspects the target. The main interaction is whatever the game deems you should do to the target. A door gets opened, a person gets spoken to, a button gets pushed. This removes a bunch of interactions, while streamlining the gaming process. Furthermore, it makes it very easy to just try out every object on every target if you are stuck. Five objects on 1 target result in 5 actions, yet 9 verbs for 5 objects on 1 target results in 45 actions, forcing you to think rather than just to try.The gameplay in the DC edition has been further simplified. For instance, actions cannot lead to player death anymore. Instead, the character will inform you that what you're about to do is definitely not a good idea. Objects are highlighted on the screen, so they're very easy to find. While carefully examining the screen makes you think about what objects would be interesting to inspect, highlighting the objects removes this entirely. While it can be cumbersome, I personally feel it is part of the game and do not consider this an improvement. At the very least, this should have been an optional setting we could enable or disable.Hints are certainly a good addition to the game. Nowadays with the easy access to walkthroughs, the temptation is too large to just ruin the game for yourself if you really get stuck (it keeps getting easier and easier to resort to a walkthrough). Hints will help you out, but still make you think. This is an excellent solution to the widespread availability of walkthroughs.Talking to NPCs in the game is done by using avatars/player faces (or however you want to call it). I'm not a big fan of those, as I prefer the old method where text was displayed above the character in a distinct color. This is probably just nostalgia speaking, though, so I can hardly blame the devs for making this alteration.More ContentThe DC edition has more scenes than the original, and that's fantastic. Unfortunately, it seems not all of those scenes are voiced by the same characters and at the same audio quality. In some cases this is really noticable, even without a good set of headphones. The extra scenes are very welcome, though, especially if you are a big fan of the series. It just feels like the developer either did not know how to prevent inconsistencies with the content (e.g., different graphical styles that clash, and audio quality and voice differences) or approached it in a very half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥way.ConclusionWhile the game is worth the asking price, I'm drawn on whether I would recommend the director's cut edition or the original. The DC edition has the advantage of being on the steam platform and having extra content, but it also adds some aspects you simply cannot disable that diminish the gaming experience.As a result I will recommend this game only because the original is not steam. It is a shame, though, that they did not allow you to switch between the original and the DC edition in the settings. In that case, the game would have gotten a more certain recommendation from me, and most of the criticism would be trivial.

												Broken Sword: The Shadow of the Templars is one of the most popular point-and-click adventure games made in the 1990's.  Originally released in 1996, the 2009 Director's Cut is an update that adds additional content as well as change some parts of the game, the latter which will be described later.As a note, while Nico Collard appears in most of the screenshots and in the banner on Steam, the vast majority of the game is centered around George Stobbart.  This is a heads up to those who were looking forward to playing as a female protagonist.  Having never played the original, I can only accurately comment on the Director's Cut version.  It's pretty apparent while playing where the new audio is used due to the difference in audio quality.  The newer audio sounds fuller with less static while the older ones sound a bit quieter.  Fortunately, despite the differences there's no noticeable variations between the voice acting of the same characters, which would've been jarring if there were.  Because this is not a modern remake, the artwork, while beautiful, is noticeably lower resolution, so I preferred to play it in windowed mode.  As another note, playing fullscreen on a 16:9 ratio monitor will leave the game in its original 4:3 ratio with blackbars on either side, which I prefer to a stretched image.  Also for some reason it looks like Nico Collard wasn't completely animated by hand as certain actions will replace her sprite with a 3D model.Overall the game has solid puzzles and a good comedy vibe to a rather serious plot.   There are many locations to visit and a soundtrack to match, and there is plenty of dialogue and banter between characters.  There is a hint system if you get stuck, but I highly recommend to try your hardest to solve the puzzles yourself otherwise you may spoil your enjoyment of the game.  Despite its age, the game is not dated and is recommended to all those who enjoy point-and-click adventure games.  My wish for improvements in the game would be for more consistency between the newer assets and the game.  Also having read about the differences between the original version and the Director's Cut, I wish that this version would have all of the content available in the original and any differences between the two would've been toggable in the options.  I think these changes would've satisfied those new and old to the game.________________________Now onto the differences between the original and Director's Cut.  Because I haven't played the original, I can only comment on the more obvious changes that I've read about.- It's possible to die in the original game.- Removal of interactions with many objects in the game. This change is probably due to the nature of the times where people have more games to play and are less likely to continue if they get stuck.  The downside is less dialogue.

There you are, sitting at your computer, expecting to be taken to the cafe, when suddenly, you find yourself thrust into a new beginning, where murder, a mime, and a familiar French photojournalist of notable repute, find you delving into a realm of new puzzles, and an intriguing little mystery of its own. While the danger of death is no longer there from making a mistake, it's still remains a nice, calming title to play. While the main story and puzzles you need to solve remain unchanged, the side story involving Nicole is a welcome look extra, and the puzzles added in on both her story and George's are a nice little touch.  This Classic remains a fine example of the Point-and-Click genre, and the updated version just cements how good a game it still remains.
